posts.name: Malachi Smith
posts.cooked:
Hi, my name is Malachi and this is my rookie year on KEARNAGE, Team 2345. I enjoy building things and found out that I like to CAD with purpose when I joined the team. This is my first post on Chief Delphi and I hope to see my design on other robots as it solved a potential problem this year with Reefscape Coral and its damage potential. Please take a look and as always, constructive feedback is always welcome.

The Problem

When we started to think about how to get the coral from the reef, we noticed that it could deal some damage to the robot, specifically our exposed Rev MaxSwerve components. So I was tasked with making a cover to protect the swerve motors. The requirements for the model are that it must protect the motors from the coral, keep debris from our robot pan, and allow wires to exit the cover without creating wear points and damage them.

How I Made It

I measured all the Swerve Drive components on our 2025 Bot - Squirt and referenced the REV MaxSwerve stl files on their website to get dimensions and size… My first design was a similar shape to the finished product, but it had less fillets and a thinner shell along with the wire entrance/exit being near the bottom of the pan. This allowed more debris to get into the pan than desired. To fix that, I changed the design so that the wiring entrance/exit would be on the side nearest the interior frame perimeter. I also added some more fillets and a thicker shell to make it visually pleasing and to add structural integrity respectively… Later, I added the team’s name and number to create the finished model you can view below. Finally, I added fillets to where the wires were inserted.

Testing

We 3D printed several prototype models as we finalized the design. On our next to last print, we started testing. That 3d print run had a filament infill of 50%. Our first test was to drop the coral from 40 inches above the prototype at multiple different angles. The design survived the upright coral drop and the horizontal coral drop with slight marks and minimal damage… With those successful tests, we decided to raise the height to 60 inches to mimic the level 4 reef location and potential coral mishandling at that height. The design took its first damage at an approximately 45 degree angled coral drop from 60 inches with a large gouge and housing crack where the coral impacted the top of the cover.

.

How we fixed the problem

To strengthen the design, I changed the infill to 100% infill. Then, I increased the fillet size on the inside to help distribute the impact from the coral. After the changes, we tested it again, only to see that the coral only scratched the design without damage. Then I put it on the chassis and you can see it here

IMG_0728 1920×2560 314 KB

IMG_0728 1920×2560 314 KB

IMG_0728 1920×2560 314 KB

IMG_0730 1920×2560 274 KB

IMG_0730 1920×2560 274 KB

IMG_0730 1920×2560 274 KB

Some Tips

When printing this design, print it upside down to preserve filament and we would encourage you to use 75% or greater infill. You may need to clean out the attachment holes with a #10-12 drill bit to be able to more easily put it on the robot.

Here is my design

Please find my Solidworks Files at the following link.

Google Drive file.

STEP file https://drive.google.com/file/d/1uefgEJfCNqo-jiZPDpJkISjPd6_-hGT6/view?usp=drive_link

Closing

I hope that you will find my design useful for your own robot. Feel free to customize and add your own team name and number. Good luck and let’s Reefscape!

posts.cooked: This looks really good! Would it be possible to get the part as a STEP file?

posts.name: Malachi Smith
posts.cooked:
Thanks! Here, this link will leave you to the file

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked:
smithm11:

To strengthen the design, I changed the infill to 100% infill

What filament are you using? you usually shouldn’t have to make the infill that high .

posts.name: Malachi Smith
posts.cooked: The filament we are using is Creality petg. We originally used 50% infill but after a couple of tests it cracked and eventually broke after a few more tests. Next, we used 100% infill. This time, it deflected of off the shell without a single crack on it. We feel like the time and filament is worth to protect the motors in case a coral may land on a motor, potentially disabled you.

posts.name: Reid Ellis
posts.cooked: How many walls were you using? that’s usually more important for impact resistance than infill percentage, if you’re using PETG 6-8 walls will almost definitely be strong enough with a lower infill and probably save some material and print time.

posts.name: Malachi Smith
posts.cooked: we have two walls making up a corner and the other corner being supported by metal. We are also using PEGT filament but without 100% infill, it might break in half like it did in one of our test. It might work for a while, but it will break eventually. We think that it is better to print four instead of printing one or two extra in case if one broke.  Thank for the suggestion.
